prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author's best friend, G, is getting married, but the wedding was announced with only a month's notice. The author and three friends had already planned a trip to Australia that starts two days before the wedding. They can't cancel because they're not super rich, and it would be a huge financial loss. The friend is upset and thinks they should drop everything for her wedding.

First, I need to consider the friend's perspective. She's the one getting married, so she might feel that her close friends would make an effort to attend. But she sent out invitations with very short notice—save the dates weren't sent out, and the actual invites came last week for a month later. That's pretty short notice, even for a wedding. Normally, save the dates are sent out like 6-8 months in advance, and formal invitations a few months before. So G's timing is definitely questionable here. If she didn't send save the dates, she probably should have sent invitations earlier. 

The author mentions that they had invited G to the Australia trip and she knew about it. So G was aware that they had plans. If she had sent a save the date earlier, maybe they could have adjusted their schedule. But she didn't. Now, the trip is already planned, and they can't afford to cancel. That seems like a big commitment they've made, and they can't just drop it without financial loss. 

On the other hand, G is upset because the author and friends are not attending. But given the short notice, maybe the author isn't at fault here. The friend could have planned better. The author is trying to attend a significant trip with friends, which is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, especially if they're not rich. Financial loss is a real factor here. 

Also, the author points out that G invited 50 people, but only 20 can make it. So maybe the wedding isn't as big an event as G thinks, and others aren't able to come either. If the author had known that the wedding was going to be a big deal, they might have planned differently. 

So, putting it all together: the friend is at fault for not giving proper notice, the author had already informed the friend about their plans, and the financial loss of canceling is a legitimate reason to not attend. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong.
